One of the main probelms with nuclear power, is the waste, and although scientists are already searching for solutions they haven't come up with one yet, and until they do, more radioactive waste is produced, which has to be stored somewhere. Even if scientists come up with some idea, for example, with the possability to recycle the waste completely, it is highly unlikely that the governments of this world would spend billions on getting the waste, which is already produced and hidden, back and recycle it, instead of just keeping it buried in the ground.

And yes, in the moment, those places are relatively save, but that doesn't mean it will stay this way. And I am not talking about natural disasters here, since, I know, theoretically, it is possible to choose the most unlikely place for an Earthquake or something similar. I am talking about humanity itself.
You can not expect, that in a few thousand years, people will still remember where nuclear waste is hidden. The entire language and form of saving information could have changed drastically in the future, so how do you want to ensure, that no one will open one of the the nuclear waste hideouts while it's still dangerous ?
(and yes I know "hideout" probably isn't the right term here, but I didn't know, how to describe it better).

This idea might seem a litte bit odd from our point of view, but consider how much society has changed over the last 100 years, not to mention over the last few thousand. People back then certainly couldn't imagine a world like ours either back then, and knowledge and methods which were widely known back then are long forgotten.

I understand that nuclear energy might seem to be the only option to stop climate change, but that doesn't mean, it can't effect our world over generations. We might exchange one global crisis for an other.
Nuclear energy is by far the best option, but it's what you see vs. what you don't see, and nuclear power plants are very scary.

I think nuclear is a good energy source for usage in the transition from fossil fuels to other cleaner sources, but making it our main energy source would be bad because if we use it more, the more waste we make, and the more waste we make, the more we have to transport, and the more we have to transport, the more likely we are to experience an accident. Even with fancy technology, just about anything can fail due to unforeseen circumstances, like what happened at Fukushima, or lack of regulation. Don’t give me the “but waste is fine because there’s less of it than there are emissions” argument, either, because if we do end up using more nuclear, there will be more waste because more nuclear energy is being used.

At the very least, nuclear energy is a far better source of energy than solar or wind-based ones. Sunlight and wind might come free, but it sure isn’t free to convert them into energy. Plus you can’t store sunlight or wind the same way you can store coal, meaning you’d have too much energy in the summer (so much that you’d have to pay other people to take it off your hands) and too little in the winter (so much that you’d have to switch back to fossil fuels. And let me tell ya, switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy every winter isn’t cheap either!) Renewables cost more to run while more often than not producing less energy. Overall it’s expensive, unreliable, and just in effective. Nuclear energy is by far the best source of energy we have right now, especially if we spend more time finding out how to run it properly.

“Nuclear power is making people smarter”. How does that work you may ask? There is this condition called the “Flynn effect”. That is where there is strong evidence that average IQ’s. One can then conclude there must be other non genetic reasons for this increase in IQ. One reason is of course environmental. I am the son of a nuclear physicist and while still having been relatively young (7 years old) when the accident in Tchernobyl happened, I still remember very well when my Dads beeper went off that evening (he was working for our governments radiation protection agency). Being in Europe and therefore close to where the wind blew the radiation, as well as getting first-line information from radiation measurements all over Europe I believe i was a bit "more involved" than the general public.
All the "fuzz" after the incident, over many years to come, made me grow up with a very negative mindset about nuclear power. After having had a discussion with my Dad about nuclear power about 10 years after it happened, he was nonetheless convinced that nuclear power was definitely the path to proceed forwards, as it is more efficient and better for the environment. Eventually I changed my mind and now I do agree with him, however we need to find a way to take the biggest risk - the "Human factor" - out of the equation to make it safe in the long term.

Another issue with nuclear detractors is the prevalence of the Linear-No-Threshold assumption that no amount of radiation exposure is without risk, when this is blatantly false evidenced by the abundance of natural radiation we're exposed to at all times. I need to read them for myself someday, but I understand that there are some studies that suggest certain levels of radiation might extend human life expectancy, evidenced by the life expectancy of individuals living in areas of higher background radiation such as the Colorado plateau.


Another thing for nuclear power is that the ignition cost of fusion can be relatively cheaply overcome by fission, but the idea of fusion having no associated radiation waste precludes that option to make fission that much more feasible in the future. Moving beyond the Linear-No-Threshold model to a more accurate maximum-allowable model that maintains conservatism even in regards to risk of development of cancer as a result of higher exposure would free up some of the costs of nuclear power production. As it is, even with current regulation models, nuclear is worth the cost, but it will be even more worthwhile if we free up some of the strict regulations regarding materials such as tools required for reactor maintenance and operation not having to be meticulously analyzed for the slightest trace of activity and stored away as radioactive forcing acquisition of new tools.

I like to show a video such as this and then provide a transcript to go along with questions to assist students. It is a simple and effective accommodation.  Here is a corrected and usable transcript:


3 REASONS WHY NUCLEAR ENERGY IS AWESOME (PART 3/3)

Three reasons why we should continue using nuclear energy:


1. Nuclear energy saves lives. In 2013, a study conducted by NASA found that nuclear energy has prevented around 1.8 million deaths. Even if you include the death tolls from Chernobyl and Fukushima, nuclear energy ranks last in death per energy units produced. While nuclear waste is really toxic, it's usually stored somewhere, while the toxic byproducts of fossil fuels are pumped into the air we breathe every day. So, just by reducing the amount of fossil fuels burned, countless cases of cancer or lung disease and accidents in coal mines have been avoided. If we can choose between lots of dangerous stuff being put into a deep hole and lots and lots and lots of dangerous stuff being pumped into the atmosphere, the former seems more logical. Nuclear energy feels way more dangerous though. Single catastrophic events burn into our memory, while coal and oil kill silently. It's like the death rate of flying versus driving. Even in the best-case scenario, it would take at least forty years to switch to 100% renewable energy. So, for as long as we continue using fossil fuels, nuclear energy will save way more lives than it destroys.



2. Nuclear energy reduces CO2 emissions. Nuclear energy is arguably way less harmful to the environment in terms of climate change than fossil fuels now main source energy. Since 1976, about 64 Gigatons of greenhouse gas emissions have not been pumped out thanks to nuclear energy. And by the mid-21st, century that could amount to an additional 80 to 240 Gigatons. Humanity's energy consumption is rising steadily. According to US government projections, China alone will add the equivalent of a new 600-megawatt coal plant every 10 days for the next 10 years. China already burns 4 billion tons of coal each year. Coal is cheap, relatively abundant, and easy to get to. So, it's not likely that humanity will stop using it soon. Nuclear energy might be the only way of dampening the effects of climate change and preventing a catastrophic man-made global warming. Compared to the other things we do; nuclear energy is relatively clean. So, even if it is a good idea to quit nuclear energy long term, it might be a good solution for the next hundred years or so, compared to the alternatives.



3. New technologies. Maybe technology will solve the problem of nuclear waste and dangerous power plants. The nuclear reactors we've used so far are mostly outdated technology, because nuclear innovations stopped in the 1970s. There are models, like the thorium reactor, that could solve the problem altogether. Thorium is abundant, really hard to turn into nuclear weapons, and up to two orders of magnitude less wasteful than current nuclear reactors. The waste material might also be only dangerous for a few hundred years, in contrast to a couple of thousand years. One ton of thorium is estimated to provide the same amount of energy as 200 tons of uranium or 3.5 million tons of coal. So, while we cannot know for sure if alternative nuclear technology will keep its promises, shouldn't we at least do more research before we forego an opportunity to solve lots of humanity's current problems? It might not be an easy challenge, but that hasn't stopped us before. So, should we use nuclear energy? There are risks involved in any great human endeavor, and we have to make an informed decision, rather than rely on gut feeling.

Nuclear powerplant waste has never been a problem (waste from weapons programs, like at Hanford, is another story, but is unrelated to power production). The "high level" waste, which needs to be stored for a couple thousand years is an insoluble, solid, ceramic. So it can't really "leak" and it won't dissolve in water or get into the water supply unless you intentionally put it there. The only realistic danger is that the miniscule amounts of gas that is produced by decay (which will be slightly radioactive) escapes. But This is easy to detect, and easy to patch.
Another nice thing is that there isn't very much of it: After decades of nuclear power, all the high level waste produced in the US would fit inside a football stadium 2 stories high. That's from 20% of the US's electrical power for the last couple decades. For any industry, that's minuscule.
Non-high level radioactive waste only needs to be stored for a hundred years ago until it's barely more reactive than natural ore. And if you're worried about it: remember that the medical industry produces far more low-level radiation than the power industry, so closing nuclear plants wouldn't make much of a difference.
The other main concern is weapons proliferation. But making a nuclear weapon from powerplant waste is nearly impossible: nobody's ever seriously considered it (not the US, not Russia, not North Korea, and as far as we can tell, no terrorists have even tried). To produce these weapons, you need specialized reactors: this is what North Korea has been trying to do. Even if they just made a "dirty bomb" (which is just a regular bomb with radiactive material mixed in), the effects would be tiny: a handful of people near the bomb would have slightly elevated chances of getting cancer in the next couple decades. You know what's easier and more effective for terrorism than a dirty bomb? A regular bomb.

Otherwise, the effects of low levels of radiation are tiny, if they exist. We spent the entire cold war testing radiation on humans and animals and in every case, low levels of radiation showed basically no sign of causing damage. In some cases, it even appeared to decrease cancer rates. How many things have we spent decades studying, but still can't tell if it's dangerous? Basically, the method governments use to "estimate" how many people will be killed by a radiation leak (known as the Linear No-Threshhold) is known to be overly conservative. So when a number is given for the "deaths caused by Fukushima" (or Chernobyl) we know it's actually far less than that. As another example: during and after Fukushima, not a single member of the public received a notable dose of radiation. And only about 40 workers received higher-than-accepted doses: most likely, none of those will die from it. Chernobyl was far worse, but in a region where coal mining, heavy smoking, and heavy drinking are common, the local cancer rates are pretty nominal.

Most nuclear disasters were the result either a) Natural disaster at the reactor (Fukishima) or b) Really stupid design and inept engineers (Chernobyl and to a degree 3 Mile Island) . Chernobyl was really poorly made, and the operators were insufficiently trained. They shut down the cooling system for a test. Rule number one of a nuclear plant DO NOT SHUT DOWN THE COOLANT SYSTEM! EVER!.The coolant was liquid graphite (a high explosive). The Soviet government took 3 days to respond. There were no containment towers (something that all US and pretty much every modern plant has). A true mark of their stupidity, some of the Chernobyl reactors were kept in operation until 2004!  How dumb do you have to be to not shut that place down. We are lucky it didn't explode again. Well designed and maintained nuclear power is much safer. The biggest issue is waste disposal, and we already have a good idea how to do this but many countries keep it trapped under political squabbling. In the US we lack a disposal site because every time we try to make one whatever state it's in screams tha we need to put it somewhere else and that it isn't fair to them. They all want a site but no one is willing to hold the ball. This is essentially what happened with the really promising Yucca Mountain site under the Obama administration (and no I am not anti-Obama, that was just a really big mistake). (Their may have also been Native American land claims involved, which would be far more legitimate, but I find it really hard to find substantial and credible evidence of such claims being made, only internet rumors. If anyone could present credible evidence of this I would revise my position).

(Try having someone attempt to ram a pipeline down your county when your entire county voted not to do it, and see how you like it! Not kidding, in the county I live in, THIS IS A THING. We said no pipeline, they do it anyway.)

What I would rather see is just a general expenditure to update all of our infrastructure, especially the electrical grid, in its entirety rather than expanding one fuel source over another, then have a portion of taxes in each state set aside to research things like fusion, superconducting power cables, better solar panels and batteries, ect. We're wasting time and money and increasing odds of an accident by just building new infrastructure where there's no need to do so. There is in fact a considerable economic incentive to developing thorium-based reactors: The abundance of processed thorium.

Most thorium that has been extracted, has come from the mining of rare-earth metals, typically the sorts of metals used to make electronic devices. But where those rare-earths are highly sought after, the same can't be said for thorium. There currently is no market for it; there's no use for it, so mining companies have to spend millions of dollars to process it so it can then be stored. As a result there is thousands of tonnes of thorium lying round, (well, buried in containers actually). But think about that.

Here is this mineral that has been mined, but is currently little more than waste that mining companies are wasting money on. But if thorium reactors were built, mining companies could turn that millions of dollar lost, into many millions more gained. And like with any new technology, an injection of new money into the economy from thorium-based technology would grow the economy.

Just a note to update the new tech section. There is a fusion test going on fairly soon that is intended to serve as a model of safe, clean nuclear energy. The ITER project will build a deuterium-tritium fusion reactor in France. The reactor will generate plasma and magnetically contain it to spare the reactor from the insane heat (10 times hotter than the core of the sun) it will produce. Should the confinement fail though, the plasma will immediately stop fusion upon contact with the reactor wall because plasma can only self sustain in as near perfect conditions. Conditions which do not involve adding new elements to the recipe. Neither deuterium nor tritium produces a long lived waste. Granted that still does mean we will be stuck with hazardous waste for ~100 years but a plant will only need 250 kilos of material per year. That's compared to the 27 tons per plant per year used by light water reactors. It's estimated to be able to produce it is estimated to produce up to 1.7 gigawatts and be slightly more expensive per kilowatt than fission until the technology is developed and adopted further.

It's not a replacement to current technologies like solar wind or hydroelectric but it is should be a part of a green future. Solar, wind and hydro are small power generators and slightly sporadic depending on your climate. Fusion can be used to fill batteries for rainy days or disasters and act as power hubs for large draws on the grid. Things like our houses, cars, schools offices can form their own power ecosystems and either be supplemented or backed up by the fusion grid.

But with renewables now falling at or below the parity line for grid generation, it's going to be prohibitively expensive for nuclear. NuScale is looking to come to market in the next few years with their modular reactors, but it's too late. Especially when you look at auctions going through in some places for an estimated price of sub 4 cents per kWh w/o subsidies.

I guess we should take a big group of scientists and start rethinking nuclear energy. If we specialize some competent people, there is a solution (as I believe the past decades have showed us). We will deplete our supply of coal and fossil fuels at some point in the future. What then? Average people living in your standard civilization like to have inexpensive food, clean water, and inexpensive electricity. So when coal and fossil fuels become so scarce and so expensive that these three main items start to become so expensive as to be burdensome to the average Joe, then I would guess that the public at large will start looking ravenously for any energy resource that can give them back their comforts they had been accustomed to. Nuclear will begin to look a lot more favorable as an option. We will have around 200 years worth of Uranium if we choose not to use breeder reactors. This will probably appear to be the favorable option to the mathematically illiterate public. Towards the end of the 200 year period, the same issues will begin to appear and the public will begin ravenously looking for source of energy to provide them with their comforts that they've been accustomed to. Then all of a sudden breeder reactors that convert this 200 years of Uranium waste into useful fuel will begin to look like a great idea. Then the new energy system should remain sustainable on the current reserves for the next 30,000 years. This should provide ample enough time for us to begin harvesting the mineral resources of the rest of the solar system. Imagine finding a huge cache of Uranium scattered around Deimos, then our civilization could have the energy to sustain itself even longer!! This isn't even taking into account what would happen if we started making use of Thorium. Dense sources of energy are everywhere! It's simply a question of having the will to use it. Energy scarcity is an illusion, unless your politics make it a reality.

A couple of points:

During point one you say that "so for as long as we continue using fossil fuels nuclear energy will save way more lives than it destroys" yet just seconds earlier you referenced data that showed that per unit energy generated, nuclear energy is the best option, even including all other fossil fuel alternatives and all renewable energy generation methods. This is not conditional on the continued use of fossil fuels.

Throughout you put an addendum on each positive point to fossil fuels that it would still be a good idea to end nuclear energy generation in the long term, yet provide no data/justification for this. Collecting diffuse energy sources (wind, solar, tidal) will always be resource intensive simply because you need to collect energy over a massive geographic area to match the energy dense alternatives. The push for PV solar in some western nations is driving a massive, environmentally destructive expansion of high grade silicon production. Silicon which is refined with energy from coal power plants and uses chemicals far more toxic than could ever come from a coal or nuclear power plant (also, toxicity and radioactivity are different things, a nitpick for point 1). To switch to renewable for even a significant minority of global energy generation would require a huge expansion in mining simply to get the raw materials for the volume of PV generators, thermal generators, batteries (another highly environmentally harmful industry that is ignored because it happens out of sight in china) and generator materials (because you are running far more small generators at low efficiency than a few massive generators at high efficiency). Diffuse energy sources suck for the enviroment, the environmental footprint will always be huge and you cant improve it because you run up against physics, not technical limitations.


If you think nuclear should be given up long term, explain why another option is better. The only alternative to fission (and the thorium reactors are very promising and could even compete with this if they pan out) is fusion if you are looking to minimise humanities environmental footprint. However fusion is still in its very VERY early experimental stages and it has not been demonstrated that the current issues are technical and not caused by simple physics (is it possible to get more energy out of fusion than is required to maintain the magnetic bottle the fusion takes place within?) A German research group recently had some developments but it is still up in the air.

Even then fusion is so tricky running a fusion plant would be like balancing a bowling ball on a pencil. It requires constant corrections and adjustments to keep running. What you want is a middle ground between immediate shut-down and a runaway reaction. So if you don't micromanage the system physics keeps the system stable without running out of control or shutting down. Previous gen nuclear reactions run out of control but the liquid fluoride thorium reactor design self stabilises. Too hot and the liquid fuel expands and the reaction slows, too cold and the liquid contracts and the reaction speeds up (higher density = faster reaction in nuclear fuels).

So like the video says, if you want to solve the energy problem, push for energy research, prevent the blocking of nuclear energy research by calling representatives and opposing environmental laws designed by fear and ignorance and supporting laws that encourage research. We have never gone backwards by knowing more than we used to.

Coal power plants pump a massive amount of radioactive particles in the air and nuclear power can actually recycle waste fuel through recombination recycling. Finally you have to remember that chernobyl and fukishima actually show the reliability of nuclear power. It took like 20 years of neglect, a built in defect, and an incompetent team of engineers and buearucrats to cause the incident at chernobyl. Basically if you think nuclear energy is a bad idea, you're an idiot.

People, do some research - haven't any of you heard of Gen IV reactors? For example, the Integral Molten Salt Reactor or IMSR (made in Canada) is a completely different kind of reactor which:
1. Cannot melt down, as the fuel/salt mix is already in a molten state
2. Creates extremely small amounts of waste, which are only radioactive for a couple hundred years (instead of 20,000!)
3. Can use spent Uranium as a fuel - or Thorium, which is as plentiful as lead, and safe enough to hold in your hand
4. Does not create usable bomb-making material (Plutonium) - so no proliferation problems
5. Is much smaller and less expensive than the huge outdated reactors in use all over the place
6. Is completely walk-away safe - so worst case scenario is that the plant shuts down and cools off by itself
... and many many more benefits

I'd be for pro-nuclear energy if it wasn't for the catastrophic damage potential it has with our current technology. Sure it's more efficient and less harmful than the current methods we use to generate energy, but once a nuclear reactor goes meltdown, everything in a 10km radius is forever gone. No human can go near there again without extensive protection, and even that will not guarantee you safety from radiation. And radioactivity lasts for millenniums! MILLENNIUMS!!! And I don't even need to point out the radioactive wastes that are stockpiled over the years. Sure coal and gas are tons more wasteful than nuclear reactors, but at least that can be reversed in just a few years by strengthening ecosystems and promoting clean air initiatives. Nuclear waste, on the other hand, cannot be fixed no matter what you do (unless someone brilliantly devises a way to use such radioactive waste) and won't effectively wear out long into the future. People are quick to assume coal and gas are just a short-term solution to a long-term problem, but nuclear energy is just as risky as they are. I'd go even far as to say that if it screws up, the tens of thousands of years worth of damage it does far outweighs the risks of using coal and gas. In that same span of time lost due to a nuclear disaster, we could've already generated trillions worth of energy with the current methods today.

I'm more for the expansion of alternative energy, such as geothermal plants, wind farms, solar farms, hydroelectric plants, and especially biofuel. Research and development into low-risk, but highly valuable renewable energy sources we currently are not taking advantage of will remove the need to constantly search for new materials to power our generators and ensure that catastrophes are minimized to the fullest.

The problem is, there are produced more radioactive waste, than there are decaying, and the waste we have today, have many years to go, whilst still more is produced. And where will this waste be stored? "Not in my backyard". The waste surely will not be hidden in big cities, but rather in places where fewer people live. Whilst this might seem fun and fluffy, it is really just giving all the problems away to people who have had no part in the decision making at all, effectively making the lives of countrymen worse. An example of this is the nuclear waste that Denmark possesses, where the nuclear waste will be forced upon specific communes if necessary. It is worth mentioning that the waste will be hidden places in the communes, which are far away from where people actually live; nevertheless it is still making communes less attractive to live in bringing numerous problems for the communes involved. 

This of course, will further the centralization, making the hopes of decentralized societies, where people can decide for their own life, even worse. The other thing that, for me, seals the deal, is nuclear reactors in space.

Try all you want to power an interplanetary spacecraft with chemical rockets, solar power, a dam (somewhere) or any other means, it won't work well.

There are designs for gas core nuclear reactors with high thrust, high thrust/weight, and simultaneously a specific impulse of 2800 seconds running on Hydrogen, the most plentiful stuff in the universe.

Compare to chemical rockets with just 450 seconds running on Hydrolox, 350 on Kerolox, and 250 on solid fuel.

Or ion thrusters, which, while readily obtaining specific impulses in the thousands, ALWAYS have a tiny thrust/weight ratio, and take months or years to burn.

Light sails can't be made practical at this distance from the sun without the sail being huge.

Solar will blacken huge swaths of the terrain, and is limited to specific parts of the world. Additionally, one needs giant batteries to make solar farms and wind farms work. These batteries are expensive, heavy, toxic, and highly flammable. If a densely packed battery storage zone were to ignite, it would probably burn unstoppably until all of the energy had been released.

Nobody has as-of-yet found a way to transport Terawatts of power thousands of kilometers cheaply.

The regions of the world where solar power works best also tend to be politically unstable and largely uninhabited and unguarded. There is no way a solar farm that remote could be paid for by the locals at the present time, so that means a foreign company/country would need to build it there. The risks if it were to be nationalized or worse, attacked, would be huge.

Wind power takes even more space that solar power, and it kills flying animals. Furthermore, wind turbines are prone to being damaged by storms.

Hydroelectric dams kill fish. Additionally, they radically alter the terrain and also present a wartime target likely to flood cities and towns with little warning. Finally, they can only be built in places where massive rivers exist.

Geothermal power is not practical everywhere. Additionally, in the places it is most practical, it tends to cause major disruption to the local environment.

Finally, nuclear power can be put in any large structure or vehicle. You can't make an airliner that runs on solar power, much less wind power. You can't make anything mobile that runs on geothermal, and you can't make anything that has its own hydroelectric dam. If you want a compact, portable, high-power, light, high-energy power source, nuclear is the only one.

The most deadly energy source is actually hydroelectric. Millions have been killed by floods caused by hydroelectric power plants. And given that the US has such shitty infrastructure they dams go decades without being inspected, I'd prefer to live right next to a nuclear power plant than anywhere near hydroelectric power.

Two comments, because I love your videos.  <3

Your point number 2 is using the wrong chemical symbol.  It's a small thing, but it makes the presentation look ignorant of basic chemistry.  "Co2" is diatomic cobalt, not carbon dioxide.  Carbon dioxide is "CO2".

Now for the bigger criticism (I apologize in advance if this seems too harsh).  I fear your bias is apparent in these videos, and it has negatively affected the quality I've come to expect from your work.  I don't have a strong opinion in either direction on nuclear fuel usage, but neither side is well-explored in these two videos, and it looks like you've done zero research on the importance of nuclear as a fuel source in developed nations.  In particular, this video is substantially lacking in hard fact.  You speak in hand-wavy terms, making points anyone would imagine, and don't quote much statistical data.  It looks under-researched.  You also couch your arguments repeatedly in this video, but not in the other video.  There are many "maybe" words, and many places where before you even begin to make a point, you try to undercut it first with a counterpoint.  For example, in the beginning of your third point, you start by referring to nuclear power plants as a "dangerous problem", which completely contradicts your initial point that nuclear power is the least dangerous power source.  There's a severe slant to what you're saying here, and it's really, really obvious if you have a scientific or literary background.

I don't disagree with you about the troubles of using nuclear as an energy source, but it's very obvious from both videos (this one in particular) that you stand in strong opposition to nuclear power.  These two videos are probably the most unprofessional ones you've produced in an otherwise stellar lineup, even though they're still well-made from an artistic perspective and do provide some good information.  I encourage you to do more research on both sides of this issue, because I agree it is an extremely important one.  It is, unfortunately, very difficult to get an unbiased perspective on this topic due to the political weight and aggressive monetary interests it is usually saddled with (this tends to be true for most environmental issues).  It would be nice to see a more balanced attempt.

"There are models, like the thorium reactor, that could solve the problem altogether"

This is, to say the least, inaccurate.  

India just put their first Thorium reactor online - however, this is just another pressurized water reactor.  High pressure and low burnup are responsible for the major safety and waste issues concerning nuclear energy.  Thorium does nothing on its own to reduce nuclear safety issues or reduce fuel waste.  

What you're looking for is molten salt reactors and, to a lesser extent, metal-cooled fast reactors.  Both operate at low pressure (no boom) and with strong negative temperature coefficients of reactivity (reactor gets too hot, reactor shuts down).  Both are capable of high breed rates (low fissile / high breedable input -> all of it fissions = very low waste per erg).
In both videos, you portray nuclear waste as a liquid held in simple barrels.  Neither of these attributes are true; spent nuclear fuel is a solid, and it's stored in large, well-shielded casks.

Though the cons are really potent in terms of contamination and improper use of storage, those were back then when we did not have the advanced technology we have nowadays (But the tragedies caused do have LONG term effects). We should at least look into improving the old nuclear reactor systems we have in place so that we can find new ways to possibly contain the waste produced. Thorium reactors would be a nice change of pace alongside keeping plutonium and uranium ones should recycling the said materials be needed before storing. In terms of nuclear proliferation like what's going down in Iran, regulation and check ups is a MUST when such technology is within the hands of countries with very shady backgrounds (Iran has been known to go back on its promises. The US on the other hand has shown more control on its nuclear stockpile like the disarming of warheads in the end of the Cold War). Overall, as long as we look into the research of nuclear energy and keep a close watch on the possible flaws and how we and other countries use them, I can see this fairly new energy source being a good alternative to fossil fuels when we run out of them (Which might be a rather long time given the amount of untapped reserves)

Thank you guys for covering (however briefly) the promise of thorium, however, the relevant advance which will push nuclear into the 21st century is not necessarily the fuel but the reactor - specifically Molten Salt Reactors. Terrestrial Energy in Canada is in the development stage of a uranium IMSR (integrated) which will be the first commercial reactor of its kind in North America.  Although renewables are great, the scaling and storage problems seem virtually unsolvable, at least in the scope of powering our civilization as it is today.  We need broad implementation of new nuclear power and likely the total decommissioning of coal plants if we're going to survive the century.

To expand on the "thorium reactor" talking point, it isn't the thorium that makes thorium reactors useful for all the reasons mentioned, it is the reactor itself

There are many advanced reactor concepts that have complete fuel burnup like a thorium molten salt reactor, and there are many thorium reactor concepts that are no better than current designs.  That is a floppy way of saying all the benefit of things like "thorium" reactors comes nearly entirely from the reactor.  

We have an entire generation of nuclear designs that can address waste and safety concerns, most of which don't use thorium. Some of those designs are even molten salt reactors, just without thorium.  Thorium makes a convenient talking point to introduce advanced reactors into the conversation, but know that the conversation about advanced reactors is much broader than just "We can do it with thorium reactors!", as the diversity of reactors that exist and could exist is SO much broader and more interesting than this!  So, you can be excited about thorium reactors, go right ahead, but perhaps augment it with "I am excited about advanced nuclear reactors, which include thorium reactors"...or something :D

This video has really put me into perspective. I've never spend enough time to look at the other side of the argument, and I must say that, now that I've heard about thorium reactors, I kinda think I changed my mind about nuclear energy.

To me the arguments themselves are almost minor compared to the way the arguments are made.

As far as I can tell the negative side largely relies on sweeping generalisations and appeals to emotion that just don't really add up. I've yet to see a claim you can't argue with.

On the positive side I see mostly evidence based arguments that are based in quantitative analyses, and which pay attention to the details.

Maybe I'm biased (I dunno, I actually see myself as quite the tree hugger) but there's just no contest, the only thing I see working for the anti nuclear side of the argument is fear and misrepresentation, it just doesn't stand up to scrutiny...

Okay, I've watched both vides and I have to say Nuclear comes out stronger. The two of the three criticisms of Nuclear outlined in the 'Nuclear energy is terrible!', accidents and waste, are effectively addressed in this video. Namely that Nuclear saves lives relative to Fossil Fuels and that CO2 waste is far worse than Nuclear waste. 

The Nuclear weapons thing is the only argument not really addressed (aside from the Thorium bit). But we are not in the Cold War anymore. Full-scale conflicts between states are very rare nowadays (see Kurz Gesagts 'Is War Over?' video) and conflicts bad enough to devolve into nuclear war are difficult to imagine. Besides, at this point any country determined enough to develop nuclear weapons (at the cost of losing face internationally), already can. A fear of nuclear weapons alone is not a good enough reason to block nuclear power.
